description: From Middle English myscreaunt, miscreaunt, from Old French mescreant (1080) "mis-believer", present participle of mescreire "to misbelieve" (modern m√©croire).

adjectives.description: miscreant (comparative more miscreant, superlative most miscreant)

entries.meaning: Lacking in conscience or moral principles; unscrupulous.
One who has behaved badly, or illegally.
examples: The teacher sent the miscreants to see the school principal.

entries.meaning: One not restrained by moral principles; an unscrupulous villain.
examples: A meagre Catchpole hurries me to fail; No Miscreant, so remorseless, ever toreThy Journals, Fog, or knock'd at Franklin's door

entries.meaning: (theology) One who holds a false religious belief; a misbeliever.
examples: Before thine eyes, thou mild and blessed one, said he, half aloud, are these miscreants daring to hold their market, and trafficking in their hellish drugs
